qas.question: What sort of thinkers were Foster and Luce?
What book was written by A.A. Luce?
What year saw the publication of Sense without Matter?
Who wrote A World for Us: The Case for Phenomenalistic Idealism?
Whose work is Sense without Matter regarded as updating?
When was The Case for Idealism published?
What aspect of Berkeley's writing did Foster modernize?
What did Foster publish after A World For Us?

context: A. A. Luce and John <a3_0>Foster<a3_0/> are other <a0_0>subjectivists<a0_0/>. Luce, in <a1_0><b6_0>Sense without Matter<b6_0/><a1_0/> (<a2_0><b5_0>1954<b5_0/><a2_0/>), attempts to bring <a4_0><b9_0>Berkeley<b9_0/><a4_0/> up to date by modernizing <b7_0>his vocabulary<b7_0/> and putting the issues he faced in modern terms, and treats the Biblical account of matter and the psychology of perception and nature. Foster's <b8_0>The Case for Idealism<b8_0/> argues that the physical world is the logical creation of natural, non-logical constraints on human sense-experience. Foster's latest defense of his views is in his book A World for Us: The Case for Phenomenalistic Idealism.
